sources.title: The Gay Amigo (1949) THE CISCO KIDüçï DUNCAN RENALDO
sources.description:
PizzaFLIX Presents CLASSIC MOVIE MONDAY
Stars: Duncan Renaldo, Leo Carrillo, Armida
Director: Wallace Fox
üçïNEW HD PRESENTATIONüçï
Saddle up for classic Western adventure as The Cisco Kid and his loyal sidekick Pancho find themselves wrongly accused of leading a ruthless band of border outlaws. With the U.S. Cavalry in hot pursuit, the duo must ride fast, think faster, and uncover the actual criminals before justice is lost on the wind. Directed by Wallace Fox, this 1949 Monogram Pictures release delivers action, charm, and Latin flair as Cisco and Pancho dodge danger across the Southwest.

Starring Duncan Renaldo in his iconic role as the suave, heroic Cisco Kid and Leo Carrillo as the lovable Pancho, this fast-paced B-Western blends humor, mistaken identity, and classic frontier justice. Featuring Armida as the spirited Rosita, the film showcases a rare mix of Mexican-American representation, patriotic themes, and post-war Hollywood Western tropes.

TRIVIA: The Cisco Kid is a fictional character created by O. Henry for his short story "The Caballero's Way," first published in 1907. Four actors portrayed this Western hero in 25 films during the sound era. In 1928, the first all-talking western starred Warner Baxter as the Cisco Kid, followed by Cesar Romero, Duncan Renaldo, and Gilbert Roland.

Are you a PizzaFLIX Fanatic? Join our exclusive Fan Club for dedicated Classic movie lovers: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCE34fwgW7kWr7tc7YiOWtRw/join

Perfect for fans of vintage Westerns, classic cowboy heroes, and the legendary Cisco Kid film series, this action-packed tale of honor and redemption is a must-watch for collectors and historians alike.

#TheCiscoKid #DuncanRenaldo #LeoCarrillo #ClassicWesterns #1940sMovies #MonogramPictures #BWestern #GoldenAgeHollywood #WallaceFox #LatinoCinema #OldWestAction #AmericanWestern #WesternLegends #ClassicFilmRestoration #Armida #VintageMovies

metadata.Plot: Chasing Mexican bandits, the Captain sees Cisco and Pancho ride away. Assuming they are the bandits he captures them and then lets them go. He has them followed figuring they will lead him to the entire gang. Cisco learns the editor and the blacksmith are the leaders. He makes the blacksmith think his partner double-crossed him and then joins up with him as his new partner planning to lead the entire gang into a trap.
